node.text:
Calling all daycare families! If you’re wondering how other families balance a daycare day, you’re going to love this “Day in the Life”! Chelsea and Jeremy will give you a real life glimpse into transitioning to daycare with their 5 month old Jaxson, what drop off and pickup look like for them, and how they make it work for THEIR family. Watch to see how communication and flexibility play a part in navigating this new phase.

Be sure to see the link in my bio to reach the blog and Amazon store for those referenced throughout sweet Jaxson’s day!

node.text:
Have you ever wondered what nights look like for other mamas of newborns? Grab the popcorn and join us for a sleepover with myself, 7 week old Bo, and Bo’s exclusively breastfeeding mama, Danya. You’ll get to see how my newborn class techniques are helping this family lay a healthy sleep foundation from the beginning, and how my class truly IS breastfeeding friendly! 

Click the link in my bio to reach the blog and Amazon store for resources mentioned. ❤️

node.title: Day in the Life- Sleepover with Cara!

node.text:
Are you a work from home mama or dad? Want a peak inside working from home with a new baby? Let’s spend the day with Tim and Emma and their 12 week old baby girl as they juggle work and family life. 

Be sure to click the link in my bio for my blog. Here you’ll find all the blogs referenced in this “Day in the Life” as well as the link to my Amazon store!

node.title: Day in the Life- Working From Home!

node.text:
Jump in to this “Day in the Life” as Bree and Kevin show us how their bedtime routine goes with their three littles, ages 6, 3 and 10 weeks. Bree and Kevin tackle baths, books, and bedtime together, and then Bree gives us a look at how she does it solo a few nights a week. It won’t always be perfect, but finding a routine that works for your family can be so helpful! 

Be sure to click the link in my bio for my blog. Here you’ll find all of the blog referenced in this “Day in the Life”.

node.text:
In today’s “Day in the Life”, we will  follow along with Katie, mama of twins Will and Jack! Katie shows us  how she navigates a full day with her busy 10 month olds. We’ll get an inside look at her flexible routine, and how important it is to meet YOUR babies right where they are!

Click the link in my bio to find my blog, where you will find all blogs referenced in today’s “Day in the Life”!

node.text:
In this “Day in the Life”, you’ll meet Jenna and 15.5 month old Hank! Follow along as Jenna walks us through her day navigating full-time work, daycare for Hank, tricky nap schedules, and an honest look at Jenna’s battle with PPD/PPA. Jenna’s story is full of truth, heart, and encouragement. 

If you are struggling with PPD/PPA, please know you are not alone. Reach out to your doctor, and know that Postpartum Support International is a wonderful resource available at www.postpartum.net.

Click the link in my bio to reach the website, where you will find all blogs referenced in this “Day in the Life” as well as the Amazon store!

node.text:
Check out this “Day in the Life” to meet Danya, Travis, and their two littles, Randi (3.5 years) and Bo 917 months). It’s a day off from work for  full-time working mom and dad, so this crew is packing up and headed to the beach! Watch this perfectly, imperfect day unfold with naps on the go, and navigating bedtime after a full day of fun. 

As you watch, you’ll see blogs and my Amazon store referenced. Click the link in my bio to find both the blog and Amazon store! There you’ll find all of the blogs referenced in this Day in the Life and more!

node.title: Day in the Life- Beach Day!

node.text:
⁣

⭐Be sure to tag an expecting mama!⭐⁣
⁣
Breastfeeding can feel so overwhelming. Especially in those early days when both you AND your little one aren't quite sure if you're doing it right. Today, I'd love to give you a SIMPLE way to think about it so that it doesn't feel quite as overwhelming.⁣
⁣
Here are a few quick takeaways:⁣
➡️Remove those extra blankets and clothing. Being skin-to-skin with mom prepares the baby for a good feeding.⁣
➡️Your baby’s belly button should face your belly button during a feeding. (Double-check to make sure it’s NOT facing the ceiling.)⁣
➡️Make a “C” with your hand to help fit the entire areola into your baby’s mouth. No “scissor-fingers.”⁣
➡️If your little one is falling asleep, wake that baby! Our goal is a full feeding instead of snacking.⁣
➡️And most importantly, remember: Reach out for help if you need it. IBCLCs are worth their weight in gold! ⁣
⁣
You got this, Mama! No one could do it better, because YOU are the best mama on the planet for your baby... no matter how you feed that sweet little one!🥰⁣
⁣
If you enjoyed this, and your little one is struggling with sleep, you'll love my online classes — taught from the science of a nurse and the heart of a mom! Just click the link in my bio and select your baby's age.❤️⁣
⁣
Will you share with me where you're at in your breastfeeding journey? Any words of encouragement for new moms who are just starting out?

⁣

node.title: Breastfeeding Basics: featuring a Subway Sandwich 🥪😂⁣

node.text:
⁣
⁣
Bath time...just another tool in your parenting toolbox! 🛠️⁣
⁣
⭐𝘋𝘪𝘥 𝘺𝘰𝘶 𝘬𝘯𝘰𝘸: Science actually supports a bath as part of the bedtime routine?⭐⁣
⁣
It’s true! Here’s why: ⁣
⁣
During a warm bath, blood comes to the surface of the skin. This is called vasodilation. When we get out of the tub, blood vessels are still open, so our body temperature drops a bit. This slight drop in core body temp promotes sleep for us and our babies!⁣
⁣
Baths can be so helpful, especially:⁣
✅At the end of the day: A bath given as part of a bedtime routine tells your baby’s brain that bedtime is near. This is a great way to prepare babies for night sleep.⁣
✅During awake time: Need an activity? A bath is like a giant water table filled with toys!⁣
✅When baby is fussy: The warm bath water can be very calming for cranky babies.⁣
⁣
“𝘋𝘰𝘦𝘴 𝘵𝘩𝘪𝘴 𝘮𝘦𝘢𝘯 𝘐 𝘩𝘢𝘷𝘦 𝘵𝘰 𝘣𝘢𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘮𝘺 𝘣𝘢𝘣𝘺 𝘌𝘝𝘌𝘙𝘠 𝘯𝘪𝘨𝘩𝘵!?”⁣
⁣
⁣My answer: Do what works best for YOUR family!⁣
➡️ Some parents prefer the consistency of a daily bath. (Soap is optional if his skin is dry...and don’t forget to lather him in lotion afterward!) ⁣
➡️ Others choose to do it every other day or even every third day. ⁣
There's no right or wrong answer. 💕⁣
⁣
Do baths relax or energize your baby? When’s your favorite time to give him/her a bath?⁣

node.text:
Let’s talk about BABY ACNE!⁣
⁣
You may notice small red bumps across your newborn's face. The bumps can even look irritated or a bit inflamed when he cries. ⁣If you’ve never seen it before, it can cause your alarm bells 🚨 to start ringing. “Is my baby sick? Is she having a reaction to something?” ⁣
⁣
Let me reassure you! Baby acne is so common within the first few weeks of life and not in any way harmful to your little one, but it’s always a good idea to have your doctor see it.⁣
⁣
“Alright...but what can I do about the baby acne?!” Here are a few tips: ⁣
⁣
DO:⁣
✅Gently wash using a clean washcloth and water⁣.⁣
✅Pat baby’s face dry after washing⁣.⁣
✅Keep baby’s face clear of spit-up.⁣
✅Allow time for the acne to clear up.⁣
✅Continue taking so many pictures of your beautiful baby!⁣
⁣
DON’T:⁣
🚫Use acne treatments. ⁣
🚫Use scented baby washes.⁣
🚫Pinch, pick, rub, or squeeze baby acne. ⁣
🚫Apply lotion.⁣
⁣
The good news is: Baby acne will usually clear up on its own within a couple of weeks!⁣
⁣
Did your baby have acne? If so, how long did it last? Tag a new/expectant parent so that baby acne doesn’t take them by surprise!

node.text:
“𝘞𝘢𝘪𝘵 𝘢 𝘮𝘪𝘯𝘶𝘵𝘦 𝘊𝘢𝘳𝘢...𝘠𝘰𝘶 𝘸𝘢𝘯𝘵 𝘮𝘦 𝘵𝘰 𝘱𝘶𝘵 𝘮𝘺 𝘣𝘢𝘣𝘺 𝘪𝘯 𝘢 “𝘚𝘈𝘊𝘒” 𝘵𝘰 𝘴𝘭𝘦𝘦𝘱?!?⁣”⁣
⁣
YES! I love using “sleep sacks” once a baby transitions out of the swaddle... through age 2+! 💗💗💗⁣
⁣
𝗪𝗮𝘁𝗰𝗵 𝘁𝗵𝗶𝘀 𝘃𝗶𝗱𝗲𝗼 𝘁𝗼 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻:  ⁣
✅ The benefits of a sleep sack⁣
✅ When to use a sleep sack⁣
✅ What's a “TOG rating” and how can it help⁣
✅ When you should stop using a sleep sack⁣
✅ Some of my favorite brands⁣
⁣
Do you HAVE to use a sleep sack? Of course not!⁣
But I do think they can be helpful tools for great baby sleep!⁣
⁣
If you are dealing with sleep struggles that a sleep sack just won’t fix, click the link in bio. I have online courses and resources that will help you!⁣ 💕⁣
⁣
Does your little one wear a sleep sack? What’s your favorite brand and why? What was the most helpful thing you learned from this video?⁣
⁣
𝘚𝘭𝘦𝘦𝘱 𝘣𝘢𝘨𝘴/𝘴𝘢𝘤𝘬𝘴 𝘧𝘦𝘢𝘵𝘶𝘳𝘦𝘥 𝘪𝘯 𝘵𝘩𝘪𝘴 𝘷𝘪𝘥𝘦𝘰: @halosleep, @woolino, @kytebaby, @nestedbean, @snuggybuddybaby

node.title: Sleep Sacks, Sleep Bags, Wearable Blankets

node.text:
If you're struggling with naps while in quarantine, these 10 tips are for YOU!💤⁣
⁣
But first, I need to share something with you: This video was filmed back in March — when getting outside was much easier, and there weren't as many closures and restrictions. Honestly, we had NO idea what the rest of 2020 would look like.⁣
⁣
We're getting into the winter months now, with colder weather and less daylight. Some places are entering another wave of lockdown. This means that you're going to have to be even more creative with your awake time activities!⁣
⁣
Can I ask...⁣
➡️Which tip did you find most helpful?⁣
➡️Which one do you really need to focus on?⁣
➡️How are you helping your baby get physical during this season?⁣
➡️Is going outside even an option where you live? ⁣
⁣
Please remember: your little one can read you like a BOOK. 📖⁣
It's true! Babies may not know that there's a pandemic, but they know that something is different. Challenging naps are NOT uncommon when life gets a bit derailed from our norm.⁣
⁣
Head to today's stories for links to all the resources I mentioned in this video. I truly hope this is helpful. ⁣
⁣
Tag another parent! We are all in this together! And...you've got this!💪

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Taking Cara Babies: Baby Sleep on July 29, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'There's no place like home. Where do you call home? What's the best thing about where you live? taking cara babies'.

node.text:
Here, I’ll go first!⁣
⁣
I’m a Kansas girl — born and raised. (Rock Chalk! ❤️💙) But...⁣
⁣
Twenty two years ago, I accepted a traveling nurse position in Phoenix, Arizona. It was only a 13-week assignment, and I never left! 🤷‍♀️⁣
⁣
Arizona is now my home sweet home and I LOVE it here…from November until April! 😂 🌵⁣🌴☀️⁣
⁣
Phoenix is truly a gem — the amazing people, the sunny weather, and the great shopping. But, the best part about it? Every season is just a short drive away!⁣
⁣
❄️You can be skiing in the snow within 2 hours.⁣
🏔Hiking the red rocks of Sedona within 1.5 hours.⁣
🏖Or relaxing on the beach within 5 hours!⁣
⁣
If you’ve never visited here, I highly recommend it!⁣
⁣
Your turn!

node.text:
As soon as you feel like you’ve settled into a comfortable, predictable routine...it seems like EVERYTHING changes. 🤪 ⁣
Think your baby might be ready to drop a nap? ⁣
Here are the signs that it's time!⁣
⁣
𝘠𝘰𝘶'𝘳𝘦 𝘢𝘵/𝘯𝘦𝘢𝘳 𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘢𝘱𝘱𝘳𝘰𝘱𝘳𝘪𝘢𝘵𝘦 𝘢𝘨𝘦 𝘳𝘢𝘯𝘨𝘦 ⁣
𝘈𝘕𝘋...⁣
1. The last nap of the day is interfering with bedtime or pushing bedtime later than 8-8:30pm.⁣
2. Your baby suddenly doesn't seem tired and struggles to fall asleep at nap time/bedtime.⁣
3. Early morning wakings and/or sudden night wakings are becoming your new normal after having great nights.⁣
4. Your little one's long naps are suddenly and consistently short.⁣
⁣
If you see these signs 3-4 days/week, for at least 2 weeks, then it's probably time to #DropThatNap 👋⁣
⁣
⭐ 𝗜𝗳 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗯𝗮𝗯𝘆 𝗜𝗦 𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗱𝘆: check out my blog post "How to Drop a Nap" for some practical tips to make this transition a breeze. (Link in bio/stories!)⁣
⁣
⭐ 𝗜𝗳 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗯𝗮𝗯𝘆 𝗶𝘀𝗻'𝘁 𝗾𝘂𝗶𝘁𝗲 𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗱𝘆: be sure to save this reel for future reference! ⁣
⁣
Anyone in the middle of a nap transition? Who just made it through one? How did you know it was time?⁣ How long did the transition take? What’s your best advice? ⁣
⁣
@alyssaweeksphotography thank you for letting me feature your sweet boy and doggie too!

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Taking Cara Babies: Baby Sleep on July 27, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Did you know? THUMBSUCKING BENEFITS YOUR BABY BY... Promoting relaxation. Releasing endorphins in the brain. Providing comfort and security. *This is true of all non-nutritive sucking.* taking cara babies'.

node.text:
Thumbsucking is considered a "non-nutritive" form of sucking. That simply means it's a type of sucking that doesn't provide nutrition. (𝘐𝘯𝘤𝘭𝘶𝘥𝘦𝘴 𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘱𝘢𝘤𝘪𝘧𝘪𝘦𝘳, 𝘧𝘪𝘯𝘨𝘦𝘳𝘴, 𝘵𝘩𝘶𝘮𝘣, 𝘦𝘵𝘤.)⁣
⁣
But wait, you might be wondering: "𝘚𝘩𝘰𝘶𝘭𝘥 𝘐 𝘶𝘯𝘴𝘸𝘢𝘥𝘥𝘭𝘦 𝘮𝘺 𝘣𝘢𝘣𝘺 𝘴𝘰 𝘴𝘩𝘦 𝘤𝘢𝘯 𝘴𝘶𝘤𝘬 𝘵𝘩𝘢𝘵 𝘵𝘩𝘶𝘮𝘣?"⁣
⁣
𝗠𝘆 𝗮𝗻𝘀𝘄𝗲𝗿: Nope! 👎 Most littles don’t have the coordination to purposely and routinely get those hands to the mouth prior to 3-5 months. Keep your little one swaddled until you see signs of rolling. (𝘐𝘧 𝘺𝘰𝘶 𝘩𝘢𝘷𝘦 𝘢 𝘴𝘸𝘢𝘥𝘥𝘭𝘦 𝘏𝘈𝘛𝘌𝘙, 𝘮𝘺 𝘯𝘦𝘸𝘣𝘰𝘳𝘯 𝘤𝘭𝘢𝘴𝘴 𝘤𝘢𝘯 𝘵𝘦𝘢𝘤𝘩 𝘺𝘰𝘶 𝘢𝘭𝘭 𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘵𝘳𝘪𝘤𝘬𝘴!)⁣
⁣
Have more questions about thumbsucking? I have an entire post written by the amazing @speechsisters over on my blog that addresses:⁣
⭐️The benefits ⁣
⭐️The concerns⁣
⭐️When/how to help your little one move on from thumbsucking.⁣
(Link in today's stories!)⁣
⁣
Do you have a thumb/finger sucker? Who has a pacifier baby? Anyone's baby take neither?!

node.text:
Moving into a new space can feel so exciting and refreshing! But, for those with a baby, this new chapter can feel a bit overwhelming. 😅📦🏡⁣
⁣
⭐𝘉𝘦 𝘴𝘶𝘳𝘦 𝘵𝘰 𝘵𝘢𝘨 𝘴𝘰𝘮𝘦𝘰𝘯𝘦 𝘺𝘰𝘶 𝘬𝘯𝘰𝘸 𝘸𝘩𝘰 𝘩𝘢𝘴 𝘳𝘦𝘤𝘦𝘯𝘵𝘭𝘺 𝘮𝘰𝘷𝘦𝘥 𝘰𝘳 𝘪𝘴 𝘱𝘭𝘢𝘯𝘯𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘵𝘰 𝘮𝘰𝘷𝘦!⭐⁣
⁣
Here are a few more tips that can help ease the transition:⁣
✅𝗨𝘀𝗲 𝗳𝗮𝗺𝗶𝗹𝗶𝗮𝗿 𝘁𝗼𝗼𝗹𝘀 𝗶𝗻 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗻𝗲𝘄, 𝘂𝗻𝗳𝗮𝗺𝗶𝗹𝗶𝗮𝗿 𝘀𝗽𝗮𝗰𝗲. Use the same crib sheet, the same lovey, the same sound machine, and the same DARK DARK DARK environment.⁣ (Paper blackout shades are so handy when moving!)⁣
✅𝗠𝗮𝗶𝗻𝘁𝗮𝗶𝗻 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗻𝗼𝗿𝗺𝗮𝗹 𝗯𝗲𝗱𝘁𝗶𝗺𝗲 𝗿𝗼𝘂𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗲. Do the same exact routine in the same exact order that you did in your old home. This cues your baby's brain that sleep is coming even when the environment has changed.⁣
✅𝗕𝗲 𝗰𝗼𝗻𝘀𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗲𝗻𝘁! Don't start any new habits in the new house that you aren't willing to maintain.⁣
✳𝗠𝗼𝘃𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘁𝗼 𝗮 𝗱𝗶𝗳𝗳𝗲𝗿𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝘁𝗶𝗺𝗲 𝘇𝗼𝗻𝗲? I have an entire blog post on how to help your baby adjust to the new time.⁣ (Link in bio/stories!)⁣
⁣
𝗔𝗻𝗱... 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝘁𝗵𝗼𝘀𝗲 𝘁𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝗮𝗻𝘅𝗶𝗼𝘂𝘀 𝗮𝗯𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗺𝗼𝘃𝗶𝗻𝗴, 𝘁𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝘀𝗼𝗹𝗮𝗰𝗲 𝗶𝗻 𝘁𝗵𝗶𝘀: ⁣
With a little preparation and a lot of consistency, your baby will likely transition more easily than you will. ⁣A dark environment and similar routine will feel the same to your baby. Your little one will most likely exceed your expectations!⁣ 🙌⁣
⁣
With that said, if sleep becomes a struggle...don't panic! Help is available! Taking Cara Babies is here for you. Our classes and resources can help you have a good sleeper in your new home.⁣ 💕⁣
⁣
Have you moved with a baby? What did you find most helpful during the transition?

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Taking Cara Babies: Baby Sleep on July 23, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'taking cara babies Can you relateto this DM? Cara your classes nelpeo helped my baby sleep GREAT but MY sleep is a a mess! Do you have any sleep tips for mom and dad?!'.

node.text:
Have you ever thought that maybe 𝘠𝘖𝘜 could use sleep training?! ⁣
⁣
🙋‍♀️🙋‍♂️🙋‍♀️🙋‍♂️🙋‍♀️⁣
⁣
You aren’t alone! ⁣
⁣
I hear this ALL THE TIME from parents. They’ve conquered baby sleep and now they need help with their OWN sleep!⁣
⁣
There are SO many reasons why parents often have trouble sleeping. Stress, chaotic schedules, the demands of parenthood…truly, you probably have a million different things keeping you up at night. ⁣
⁣
BUT- we know that parent sleep is so VITAL to the overall well-being of you AND your baby. 💕⁣
⁣
If getting a good night’s rest has been a struggle recently, here are a few tips to get you back on track: ⁣
⁣
1️⃣ 𝗦𝘁𝗮𝘆 𝗼𝗻 𝗮 𝘀𝗹𝗲𝗲𝗽 𝘀𝗰𝗵𝗲𝗱𝘂𝗹𝗲! Just like your baby's body, your body does best when you aim for the same bedtime and wake-up range every day.⁣
2️⃣ 𝗨𝘀𝗲 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗯𝗲𝗱 𝗼𝗻𝗹𝘆 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝘀𝗹𝗲𝗲𝗽 (𝘢𝘯𝘥 𝘴𝘦𝘹 😘). If we do too many other activities in bed, our brain stops seeing the bed as a sleep cue. This can be so confusing and make it tricky to fall asleep.⁣
3️⃣ 𝗛𝗮𝘃𝗲 𝗮 𝗰𝗮𝗹𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗽𝗿𝗲-𝘀𝗹𝗲𝗲𝗽 𝗿𝗶𝘁𝘂𝗮𝗹 (with no electronics). Yes, this is the grown-up version of a bedtime routine! 😉⁣
4️⃣ 𝗖𝗿𝗲𝗮𝘁𝗲 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗽𝗲𝗿𝗳𝗲𝗰𝘁 𝘀𝗹𝗲𝗲𝗽 𝗲𝗻𝘃𝗶𝗿𝗼𝗻𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁. Just like your baby’s room, your room should be dark and kept at comfortable temperature.⁣ Feel free to add a fan or sound machine too. ⁣
⁣
𝘚𝘰𝘶𝘯𝘥𝘴 𝘧𝘢𝘮𝘪𝘭𝘪𝘢𝘳? ⁣
⁣
That’s because some of these tips are what I recommend for your BABY too!⁣☺️⁣
⁣
With the help of @psychedmommy's Dr. Ashurina Ream, we’ve created an entire blog post that focuses on helping YOU sleep. The full post includes even more sleep tips and research (link in stories.)⁣
⁣
So tell me…How is YOUR sleep? What has helped the most? What do you find most challenging?⁣

node.text:
“Okay, Cara, so 𝘩𝘰𝘸 𝘭𝘰𝘯𝘨 do I keep my baby awake between naps?" ⁣
⁣
Remember: it’s always a 𝗿𝗮𝗻𝗴𝗲, and our goal is 𝘁𝗶𝗿𝗲𝗱 𝗯𝘂𝘁 𝗻𝗼𝘁 𝗼𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘁𝗶𝗿𝗲𝗱. ⏰😴⁣
⁣
➡️Wake windows tend to be shorter earlier in the day and gradually lengthen as the day progresses. You can adjust throughout the day and day-to-day as needed. ⁣
➡️It’s a delicate balance between being awake long enough to sleep well, but not so long that we cause a meltdown. Go slowly — adding just a few minutes at a time.⁣
⁣
Here are common wake-window ranges based on your baby’s age:⁣
𝟬-𝟰 𝘄𝗲𝗲𝗸𝘀: 35-60 minutes⁣
𝟰-𝟭𝟮 𝘄𝗲𝗲𝗸𝘀: 60-90 minutes⁣
𝟯-𝟰 𝗺𝗼𝗻𝘁𝗵𝘀: 75-120 minutes⁣
𝟱-𝟲 𝗺𝗼𝗻𝘁𝗵𝘀: 2-3 hours⁣
𝟳-𝟭𝟰 𝗺𝗼𝗻𝘁𝗵𝘀: 3-4 hours⁣
𝟭𝟰-𝟮𝟰 𝗺𝗼𝗻𝘁𝗵𝘀: 4-6 hours⁣
⁣
Finding the right wake windows for your baby can be a bit of trial and error. You know you’ve got it 𝘫𝘶𝘴𝘵 𝘳𝘪𝘨𝘩𝘵 when naps & bedtime are no longer a battle and your little one is sleeping in consolidated stretches. 🙌⁣
⁣
⭐Don't forget: You’ll need to re-evaluate those wake windows about once a month during that first year.⁣
⁣
If wake windows are solid but you’re still struggling, help is available! My classes will teach you how to conquer both nights AND naps. (Link in bio.) 💕⁣
⁣
How old is your baby? What wake window range have you found fits best?

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Taking Cara Babies: Baby Sleep on July 21, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'TAKING CARA BABIES Baby sleep Tip for special situations...'.

node.text:
Did you know that after about 3-4 months of age, babies become more aware of the world around them… even at night? 🤔⁣
It's true! ⁣
⁣
Why does that matter? ⁣
➡️Well, as these older babies transition between sleep cycles, they are more likely to fully awaken if they see a parent.⁣
⁣
These tips can help!⁣
Have you implemented any of these tips at home or while traveling? How’d it go? Any other tips?

Photo by Taking Cara Babies: Baby Sleep on July 21, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'It's TOTALLY possible to have a good sleeper in any of these spaces. You just may need to get a little creative when it comes to setting up your baby's sleep environment. taking cara babies'.

Photo by Taking Cara Babies: Baby Sleep on July 21, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'The BIGGEST obstacles to good sleep in small spaces are: Your baby being able to SEE you (especially after 3-4 months old.) Your baby being able to HEAR you. 0 taking cara babies'.

Photo by Taking Cara Babies: Baby Sleep on July 21, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'If your little one is aware that parents are nearby, it's S pretty likely that she'll want to have a late-night party with ner favorite people! Swipe for tips to help. taking cara babies'.

Photo by Taking Cara Babies: Baby Sleep on July 21, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Move baby's bassinet across the room. You'll be further away so your night noises are less likely to wake baby. If baby does wake, you'll be slower to intervene. taking cara babies'.

Photo by Taking Cara Babies: Baby Sleep on July 21, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Use a room divider. If you share a room with your little one, visually dividing the space can be helpful in preventing distractions that may wake your baby. taking cara babies'.

Photo by Taking Cara Babies: Baby Sleep on July 21, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Create a bedroom from an 'unconventional' space. Did you know large closets, offices, bathrooms, and laundry rooms, can make GREAT baby nurseries?! Set up a pack-n-play and all of a sudden you have a private bedroom for your baby. (Ensure safety and adequate ventilation in these spaces) taking cara babies'.

Photo by Taking Cara Babies: Baby Sleep on July 21, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Try out the SlumberPod. This product is designed to house a pack-n-play and creates a dark, private sleep environment for your itte one. taking cara babies'.

Photo by Taking Cara Babies: Baby Sleep on July 21, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Add an extra sound machine In addition to being a soothing sound for babies, white noise is GREAT for blocking out other sounds that might wake your little one! Using one next to you and one next to baby May help you both sleep more soundly. taking cara babies'.

node.text:
That’s right! If you’ve got a new little “sitter,” it’s time to drop the mattress. ⁣
⁣
Let’s unpack this! ⁣
⁣
An infant’s head is much heavier in proportion to their body. This means your sweet little bobble-head truly is “top heavy.” ⁣
⁣
So, please remember this…⁣
⁣
⭐️𝘐𝘧 𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘵𝘰𝘱 𝘤𝘳𝘪𝘣 𝘳𝘢𝘪𝘭 𝘪𝘴 𝘭𝘰𝘸𝘦𝘳 𝘵𝘩𝘢𝘯 𝘺𝘰𝘶𝘳 𝘣𝘢𝘣𝘺’𝘴 𝘤𝘩𝘦𝘴𝘵, 𝘪𝘵 𝘮𝘢𝘬𝘦𝘴 𝘧𝘢𝘭𝘭𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘰𝘶𝘵 𝘢 𝘩𝘶𝘨𝘦 𝘳𝘪𝘴𝘬.⁣⭐️⁣
⁣
To prevent falls, aim for the top rail to hit mid-chest when the baby is in a standing position, even if your little one can't stand yet!⁣
⁣
Please tag a parent...or lots of them! Let’s prevent crib accidents. Start watching your Instagram feed, how many babies do you see standing in cribs with the mattress not quite low enough? You’ll be amazed!😱 (Be sure to see stories for more common questions about this!⁣)⁣
⁣
What age was your baby when you knew it was time? Did it catch you off guard? Anyone start from the beginning with it in the lower position? (That’s okay too, btw!)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Taking Cara Babies: Baby Sleep on July 19, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'TAKING CARA BABIES "How can I prioritize sleep when my baby is sick?" Swipe for some practicaltips!'.

node.text:
Sleep IS good medicine, but sickness often causes disrupted sleep! ⁣
⁣
For more details, be sure to check out my blog post "Sleep and Sick Season: What’s a Parent to Do?" (Link in bio/stories!)⁣
⁣
Any "sick tips" you would add? How have you dealt with baby sickness in your house? How long did it take to get your good little sleeper back?⁣

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Taking Cara Babies: Baby Sleep on July 19, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'TAKING CARA BABIES "How can I prioritize sleep when my baby is sick?" Swipe for some practicaltips!'.

Photo by Taking Cara Babies: Baby Sleep on July 19, 2021. May be an image of text that says '# Maintain a consistent nap nap-time and bedtime routine These familiar series of events cue your baby's brain that sleep is coming even when your little one isn't feeling well. taking cara babies'.

Photo by Taking Cara Babies: Baby Sleep on July 19, 2021. May be an image of text that says '#2 Allow more daytime sleep While sick it's okay to let naps extend a bit longer than normal. Check on your little one frequently. Consider waking your little one after 2.5-3 hours for any given nap for feedings to maintain hydration. taking cara babies'.

Photo by Taking Cara Babies: Baby Sleep on July 19, 2021. May be an image of text that says '#3 Camp out in baby's room Ifyou're wanting to be closer to your baby while she's sick, consider putting a mattress in her room for you to sleep on, rather than bringing her into your room. Babies sleep better in their normal sleep environment, just like you do! taking cara babies'.

Photo by Taking Cara Babies: Baby Sleep on July 19, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says '#4 It's okay to give extra help Your great little sleeper may need more support than usual when falling asleep and back to sleep in the night. If you need to rock or snuggle your little one to get him sleeping while sick, go for it! taking cara babies'.

Photo by Taking Cara Babies: Baby Sleep on July 19, 2021. May be an image of text that says '#5 Offer night feedings when needed (even if previously weaned of all feedings) If baby hasn't eaten well during the day or is struggling with vomiting or diarrhea, she may need these extra feedings. taking cara babies'.

Photo by Taking Cara Babies: Baby Sleep on July 19, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Mostimportantty. Give lots of snuggles and patience! Sick babies need a lot of extra love! taking cara babies'.

Photo by Taking Cara Babies: Baby Sleep on July 19, 2021. May be an image of text that says '"What about when baby is feeling better?" Jump right back to your normal healthy sleep habits! My online class "The ABC' of Sleep" is a plan that can be used anytime sleep is derailed and once your baby is back to 100% health, you can have your great little sleeper back in just a few days. taking cara babies'.

node.text:
Sleep sacks are one of my favorite tools to have in your sleep toolbox. 🛠💤⁣
⁣
Here are a few reasons why I LOVE sleep sacks:⁣
⁣
✅They cue the brain that it’s time for sleep.⁣
✅Unlike loose blankets, sleep sacks are safe, wearable, and actually stay on baby when rolling around the crib.⁣
✅They promote sleep by making crawling, walking, and climbing a bit more difficult. ⁣
✅They’re available in various weights and fabrics (perfect for every season!)⁣
⁣
See my blog “Sleep Sacks, Sleep Bags and Wearable Blankets” for more details and a peek at some of my favorite sleep sacks!👀⁣
⁣
Does your baby use a sleep sack? Which brand is your favorite? ⁣

node.text:
Look at all of those sweet babies falling asleep independently!😍⁣
⁣
✨Baby Sleep Tip:✨ Mastering this skill plays a HUGE part in achieving consolidated night sleep!⁣
⁣
But, here's the catch...⁣ No one actually "sleeps through the night!" We ALL wake up multiple times as we transition through sleep cycles! 😧⁣
⁣
𝗛𝗲𝗿𝗲'𝘀 𝘄𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝗵𝗮𝗽𝗽𝗲𝗻𝘀:⁣
1️⃣You wake at the end of each sleep cycle.⁣
2️⃣You briefly check your surroundings to make sure nothing has changed.⁣
3️⃣If everything looks good, you fall right back to sleep, often without even knowing you were awake.⁣
⁣
𝗕𝗨𝗧, 𝘄𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝘄𝗼𝘂𝗹𝗱 𝗵𝗮𝗽𝗽𝗲𝗻 𝗶𝗳...⁣
1️⃣You fell asleep in YOUR bed.⁣
2️⃣Two hours later, you wake up in your NEIGHBOR’S bed!!!😳 ⁣
3️⃣Would you just roll over and go back to sleep?⁣ No way! You would be so confused!😱⁣
⁣
Your baby has this SAME reaction when he wakes in a different environment than where he fell asleep. He will look for the same environment with the same interventions to fall BACK to sleep.⁣
⁣
Here's a better example... (Because "your neighbor's bed" isn't very realistic! 😂)⁣
✳If your little one is rocked/fed to sleep at bedtime, he will most likely need rocking/feeding throughout the night as he transitions between some sleep cycles. This is why falling asleep independently is VITAL!⁣
⁣
With that said, feel free to snuggle your baby and rock to sleep when desired, but falling asleep independently at bedtime will truly make your nights SO MUCH easier!💕⁣
⁣
💫Fun Fact: A small percentage of babies can be rocked/fed to sleep and sleep through the night. Remember, if it’s working for you, there’s no reason to change it!💫 ⁣
⁣
➡But…If you're struggling with this, my classes can help! Just click the link in my bio and select your baby's age to get started.⁣
➡If your little one 𝘤𝘢𝘯 fall asleep independently at bedtime, but still struggles through the night, you simply need a consistent approach to handle night wakings. My classes can help with this too!⁣
⁣
Be sure to tag me in your stories if you catch your little one falling asleep independently! I'd love to share some today!⁣
⁣
Anyone willing to share the craziest place they've ever fallen asleep?😱😴

node.text:
Parents, I have a very heavy, but important message to share.⁣
⁣
I never want to educate in a way that induces fear. But, with many of you traveling/having fun around water this summer, I need to talk to you about drowning, because it never feels like it could happen to you...until it does.⁣
⁣
⚠𝘗𝘭𝘦𝘢𝘴𝘦 𝘵𝘢𝘨 𝘢 𝘱𝘢𝘳𝘦𝘯𝘵/𝘤𝘢𝘳𝘦𝘨𝘪𝘷𝘦𝘳/𝘧𝘳𝘪𝘦𝘯𝘥 𝘣𝘦𝘭𝘰𝘸. 𝘛𝘩𝘪𝘴 𝘪𝘯𝘧𝘰𝘳𝘮𝘢𝘵𝘪𝘰𝘯 𝘚𝘈𝘝𝘌𝘚 𝘓𝘐𝘝𝘌𝘚!⚠⁣
⁣
Here are some important ways to prevent drowning and keep your little one safe:⁣
⁣
𝗔𝗿𝗼𝘂𝗻𝗱 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗵𝗼𝘂𝘀𝗲:⁣
➡ Install locks on toilets: littles are top-heavy and it only takes a bit of water.⁣
➡ Never leave a baby alone in the tub...not even for a second: It’s better to carry a dripping wet baby through the house than leaving him alone.⁣
➡ Empty ALL containers (buckets, kiddie pools, bathtubs, etc.) immediately after use and turn them upside down to prevent unintentional water collection.⁣
⁣
𝗔𝗿𝗼𝘂𝗻𝗱 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗣𝗼𝗼𝗹:⁣
➡ Never leave pool toys or floats in or around the pool: children can be tempted to reach into the pool to grab a toy.⁣
➡ Install a pool fence: baby proof your pool with a fence that is at least 4ft high, non-climbable, and has a self-latching/self-closing gate.⁣
➡ Add alarms to doors leading to the patio.⁣
➡ Can’t find your child? Always check the pool FIRST. It only takes seconds for a child to drown, which means every single second matters.⁣
⁣
𝗪𝗵𝗶𝗹𝗲 𝗮𝘁 𝗚𝗮𝘁𝗵𝗲𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴𝘀:⁣
➡ Have a designated “water watcher.”⁣
➡ Alternate “water watchers” every 15 minutes: This ensures everyone gets socialization, but kids are being actively monitored too.⁣
⁣
✳And please, look into survival swim classes for your children and CPR training for you and all caregivers. If all other preventative measures fail, this type of training may be the very thing that saves your child’s life.⁣
⁣
Please tag ALL of the parents you know! Share this post! ❤️ By sharing this post with others, you can prevent a tragedy! You can save lives!⁣
⁣
